column2: A modern practical book about cryptography for developers with code examples in Python.

column1: Open Workbook of Cryptology: A project-based introduction to crypto in Python
column2: This is a first draft of a free (as in speech, not as in beer) textbook for a one-semester, undergraduate cryptology course. It was used for CIS 491 at Colorado State University Pueblo in the spring semester of 2021.

This book provides very clear and comprehensive coverage of the usual Elementary Algebra topics, as well as some Intermediate Algebra material. It provides plenty of examples and very robust, well-constructed exercise sets.

column1: A Practical Introduction to Python Programming
column2: An introductory programming text for students with no prior programming experience.
This open access book reviews the threat pyramid, secure boot, chain of trust, and the SW stack leading up to defense-in-depth.
A textbook for Math 225 Modern Algebra Course in Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at Clark University.
This text is an introduction to algebra for undergraduates who are interested in careers which require a strong background in mathematics.

column1: Notes on Data Structures and Programming Techniques
column2: These are notes for Yale course CPSC 223: Data Structures and Programming Techniques for the Spring 2021 semester.

column1: Notes on Theory of Distributed Systems
column2: These are notes for the Fall 2020 semester version of the Yale course CPSC 465/565 Theory of Distributed Systems.
These are notes for the Yale course CPSC 469/569 Randomized Algorithms.
This book was originally (and currently) designed for use with STAT 420, Methods of Applied Statistics, at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

column1: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python 3
column2: The goal of this book is to teach you to think like a computer scientist. The programming language you will be learning is Python.
This course is an in-depth introduction to functions. Our study will be guided by some goals, and related essential questions that are designed to get at the essence of the idea of a function.
This book is an attempt to make the subject of linear algebra as understandable as possible, for a first time student of the subject.

column1: Introduction to Scientific Programming with Python
column2: A compact introduction to scientific programming. No prior knowledge of programming is needed.
Open Data Structures covers the implementation and analysis of data structures for sequences (lists), queues, priority queues, unordered dictionaries, ordered dictionaries, and graphs.

This book is used in a class called Modeling and Simulation at Olin College, which all students take in their first semester. It teaches the entire modeling process and give students a chance to practice it.
This is a monograph based on the class "Algorithmic Aspects of Machine Learning" taught at MIT in Fall 2013, Spring 2015 and Fall 2017.
This book will help you or your team making rapid progress while working on a machine learning application.
This book serves as an introductory text and survey to lifelong learning.

column1: The Coder’s Apprentice - Learning Programming with Python 3
column2: "The Coder's Apprentice" is a course book, written by Pieter Spronck, that is aimed at teaching Python 3 to students and teenagers who are completely new to programming.
A free online book whose purpose is to give the reader a thorough introduction to competitive programming.

A text book for Computer Science I at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, covering CS1 topics in a generic manner using psuedocode with supplemental parts for specific languages (including Java, C, and PHP currently).

This is on linear algebra and its interaction with analysis. It emphasizes the main ideas, both algebraic and geometric and attempts to present these ideas as quickly as possible without being overly terse.

This book highlights practical sysadmin skills, common architectures that you’ll encounter, and best practices that apply to automating and running systems at any scale, from one laptop or server to 1,000 or more.

column1: Foundations of Machine Learning, Second Edition
column2: A new edition of a graduate-level machine learning textbook that focuses on the analysis and theory of algorithms.

column1: A Brief Introduction to Machine Learning for Engineers
column2: This monograph aims at providing an introduction to key concepts, algorithms, and theoretical results in machine learning. The treatment concentrates on probabilistic models for supervised and unsupervised learning problems.

This textbook provides a comprehensive introduction to the fields of pattern recognition and machine learning. It is aimed at advanced undergraduates or first-year PhD students, as well as researchers and practitioners.
This book describes an open machine learning architecture. Including key aspects that are involved for real business use. It focuses on FOSS machine learning software and open datasets.
This free e-book is a fast-paced intro to Python aimed at researchers and engineers.

The book introduces the core libraries essential for working with data in Python: particularly IPython, NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-Learn, and related packages. Familiarity with Python as a language is assumed.

An introduction to computer programming with Python 3. Helps the readers in learning the key concepts of Python and understanding how programs work while also imparting foundational logic that can serve the readers in other domains.
This book of Python projects in machine learning tries to equip the developers of today and tomorrow with tools they can use to better understand, evaluate, and shape machine learning.

With this concise book, you'll learn how to use Python with the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS), MapReduce, the Apache Pig platform and Pig Latin script, and the Apache Spark cluster-computing framework.
This book is a useful resource for educators and self-learners alike. It is well organized, covers single variable and multivariable calculus in depth, and is rich with applications.
Cracking Codes with Python teaches complete beginners how to program in the Python programming language. The book features the source code to several ciphers and hacking programs for these ciphers.

column1: Don't Panic: Mobile Developer's Guide to The Galaxy, 17th Edition
column2: More than 20 writers from the mobile community share their know-how in dealing with topics such as accessibility in mobile apps, UX design, mobile analytics, prototyping, cross-platform development, native development, mobile web and app marketing.

column1: Linux Appliance Design: A Hands-On Guide to Building Linux Appliances
column2: This book is for Linux programmers who want to build a custom Linux Appliance and support multiple user interfaces. Topics include appliance architecture, security, and how to build simple, yet responsive user interfaces.
A must-have guide for journalism in 2017. Topics include how to protect your source and sensitive data, maintaining your anonymity online, and securing your emails.

An introductory text for a college algebra survey course.  The material is presented at a level intended to prepare students for Calculus while also giving them relevant mathematical skills that can be used in other classes.

This is a research document and a textbook for graduate students and researchers in the field of networking and system administration. It offers a theoretical perspective on human-computer systems and their administration.
This book focuses on the discrete Fourier transform (DFT), discrete convolution, and, particularly, the fast algorithms to calculate them.
An introductory course which covers the key features of the C language and its usage.
This document originated from lecture notes of mathematical statistics course taught at George Mason University. Students should be able to work through the details of "hard" proofs and derivations.

column1: Lies, Damned Lies, or Statistics: How to Tell the Truth with Statistics
column2: A free textbook for a one-semester, undergraduate statistics course. The goal of this book is to help you learn How to Tell the Truth with Statistics and, therefore, how to tell when others are telling the truth, or lies.

column1: Yet Another Introductory Number Theory Textbook (Cryptology Emphasis Version)
column2: An introduction to number theory covering basics, congruences, primes, the Chinese Remainder Theorem, Wilson's Theorem, Fermat's Little Theorem, Euler's Phi function, etc.

column1: Adaptive Web Design: Crafting Rich Experiences with Progressive Enhancement, 1st Edition
column2: This book chronicles the origins of progressive enhancement, its philosophy, and mechanisms, and reveals the countless practical ways that you can apply progressive enhancement principles using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
A history book of robust website design.

column1: Notes on Diffy Qs: Differential Equations for Engineers
column2: An introductory course on differential equations aimed at engineers. The book covers first order ODEs, higher order linear ODEs, systems of ODEs, Fourier series and PDEs, eigenvalue problems, the Laplace transform, and power series methods.

An open source textbook designed to teach ordinary differential equations to undergraduates. The books strengths will include a wide range of exercises, both computational and theoretical, plus many nontrivial applications.
This tutorial covers the basic mathematical tools used in economic theory. Knowledge of elementary calculus is assumed.
Lecture notes for Math 164: Scientific Computing, taught at Harvey Mudd College.

column1: TCP/IP Tutorial and Technical Overview, 8th Edition
column2: This book covers networking fundamentals of the TCP/IP protocol suite while also introduces advanced concepts and new technologies. It also includes the latest TCP/IP protocols.

column1: Confessions of an Unintentional CTO: Seven Years of Brutally Pragmatic Lessons in Growing and Maintaining a Web App.
column2: A book of generalised, language-agnostic advice pertinent to hacker-y web developers working on live web applications which have real-life users and all too real problems.

column1: The Design and Implementation of the Anykernel and Rump Kernels, 2nd Edition
column2: The definitive technical guide to the core of the Rump Kernel project.
This book covers the fundamentals of operating systems, including virtualization of the CPU and memory, threads and concurrency, and file and storage systems.

column1: CS Unplugged: An enrichment and extension programme for primary-aged students
column2: This book contains series of activities, games and puzzles that are suitable for people of all ages and backgrounds. Covers topics from algorithms to artificial intelligence, from binary numbers to boolean circuits, and from compression to cryptography.

column1: Signal Computing: Digital Signals in the Software Domain
column2: This book teaches students how digital signals are captured, represented, processed, communicated, and stored in computers.

column1: Programming Fundamentals: A Modular Structured Approach Using C++
column2: The approach of this text is to take learners through a progression of materials in order to develop skills of modular, structured programming. The text was written, for the most part, without consideration of a specific programming language.
This book introduces concepts in mobile, autonomous robotics to 3rd-4th year students in Computer Science or a related discipline.

column1: Microservices for Java Developers: A Hands-On Introduction to Frameworks and Containers
column2: In this hands-on, example-driven guide, Java developers and architects will learn how to navigate popular application frameworks, such as Dropwizard and Spring Boot, and how to deploy and manage microservices at scale with Linux containers.

column1: Introduction to Digital Logic with Laboratory Exercises
column2: An introduction to digital logic, starting with simple gates and building up to state machines.

column1: Cognitive Patterns:  Problem-Solving Frameworks for Object Technology
column2: This book presents the concepts and terminology of cognitive patterns and cognitive modeling. It thoroughly explains the uniqueness of cognitive patterns as an approach in modeling business systems and processes.

column1: forall x: An Introduction to Formal Logic
column2: An open access introductory textbook in formal logic. It covers translation, proofs, and formal semantics for sentential and predicate logic.
Explores the basic ideas behind statistics, such as populations, samples, the difference between data and information, and most importantly sampling distributions.

column1: [Sign-up required] Raspberry Pi Cookbook for Python Programmers
column2: Over 50 easy to comprehend tailor made recipes to get the most out of the Raspberry Pi and unleash its huge potential using Python.

column1: [Sign-up required] Practical Data Analysis - Transform, model, and visualize your data through hands-on projects, developed in open source tools
column2: A hands-on guide to understanding the nature of your data and turn it into insight. Presents a detailed exploration of the current work in data analysis through self-contained projects.
This book will familiarize you with the Scratch visual programming environment, focusing on using Scratch to learn computer science.

This textbook covers the fundamental enumeration techniques (permutations, combinations, subsets, pigeon hole principle), recursion and mathematical induction, more advanced enumeration techniques, discrete structures, and discrete optimization.

column1: Bayesian Methods in the Search for MH370
column2: An account of the work of the teams who were part of the MH370 Flight Path Reconstruction group. Defence scientists contributed a range of expertise to the search: underwater acoustics, satellite communication systems and statistical data processing.
A compilation of papers, which mostly result from The Second International Conference on Proof-Theoretic Semantics in Tübingen in 2013.

column1: SQL Server Concurrency: Locking, Blocking and Row Versioning
column2: A book for every DBA and developer who want to understand SQL Server concurrency and how to troubleshoot excessive blocking or deadlocking.
This book offers just the right level of detail so that every DBA can perform all of the most important aspects of transaction log management.
Proceeding from the Fourth International Conference on Computer Science and Information Technology (CoSIT 2017) Geneva, Switzerland, March 25-26, 2017.

Focusing on algorithms for distributed-memory parallel architectures, this book presents a rigorous yet accessible treatment of theoretical models of parallel computation and parallel algorithm design.

column1: Elementary Differential Equations with Boundary Value Problems
column2: This book is written for students in science, engineering, and mathematics who have completed calculus through partial differentiation. Readers should have some preparation in linear algebra.

column1: Statistical Analysis with The General Linear Model
column2: An introductory textbook describing statistical analysis with analysis of variance (ANOVA, including repeated-measures and mixed designs), simple and multiple regression, and analysis of covariance.
A cohesive presentation of concepts of, and methods for, causal inference. Covers causal inference without models, causal inference with models, and causal inference from complex longitudinal data.

column1: [Sign-up required] Building Machine Learning Systems with Python
column2: This book provides you with an accessible route into Python machine learning, featuring a wealth of real-world examples.

column1: [Sign-up required] HTML5 Graphing and Data Visualization Cookbook
column2: Get a complete grounding in the visual world of Canvas and HTML5 using this recipe-packed cookbook. Learn to create charts and graphs, draw complex shapes, add interactivity, work with Google maps, and much more.
Design and construct reusable, maintainable, and modular web applications with AngularJS.
Learn to code like a professional with Python – an open source, versatile, and powerful programming language.
Elementary Algebra is designed to meet the scope and sequence requirements of a one-semester elementary algebra course.

column1: Defensive Database Programming with SQL Server
column2: This book helps you to produce resilient T-SQL code that robustly and gracefully handles cases of unintended use, and is resilient to common changes to the database environment.

column1: SQL Server Execution Plans, Third Edition
column2: This book focuses entirely on what SQL Server execution plans are, how to read them, and how to apply the information you learn from them in order to boost the performance of your SQL Servers.

column1: Why Should I Care? Mobile Security for The Rest of Us
column2: A guide for a coordinated effort between employees and IT/security personnel to truly secure mobile computing in the enterprise.

How to protect yourself, your sources or your friends in the digital world? What are safe routes to take? How do you secure after your personal data? This manual aims to address these issues to help you choose your own 'level' of safety.
A free study reference guide for the education of its readers who wish to learn Electronics.
This book is written for students in science, engineering, and mathematics who have completed calculus through partial differentiation. Readers should have some preparation in linear algebra.

This book introduces readers to a rigorous understanding of mathematical analysis and presents challenging math concepts as clearly as possible. For those who want to gain an understanding of mathematical analysis and challenging mathematical concepts.

column1: Basic Analysis: Introduction to Real Analysis
column2: A first course in mathematical analysis. Covers the real number system, sequences and series, continuous functions, the derivative, the Riemann integral, sequences of functions, and metric spaces.

column1: Android on x86: An Introduction to Optimizing for Intel Architecture
column2: This book compiles the best practices and procedures associated with Android application development for devices using Intel's popular line of microprocessors.
Lecture notes for a first course in differential equations, taught at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. Included in these notes are links to short tutorial videos posted on YouTube.

column1: Let Over Lambda -- 50 Years of Lisp
column2: This book is about pushing the boundaries of what we know about programming. If you have ever wondered what lisp or even programming itself is really about, this is the book you have been looking for.
This introduction to more advanced courses in probability and real analysis emphasizes the probabilistic way of thinking, rather than measure-theoretic concepts. Its sole prerequisite is calculus.
Written by three leading researchers, Foundations of Databases presents indepth coverage of theory concerning the logical level of database management systems and surveys several emerging topics.
An introduction to probability and mathematical statistics intended for students already having some elementary mathematical background.

column1: Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction, Second Edition
column2: This textbook provides a clear and simple account of the key ideas and algorithms of reinforcement learning that is accessible to readers in all the related disciplines. Familiarity with elementary concepts of probability is required.

column1: System Design, Modeling, and Simulation using Ptolemy II
column2: This book is a definitive introduction to models of computation for the design of complex, heterogeneous systems. It has a particular focus on cyber-physical systems, which integrate computing, networking, and physical dynamics.

column1: Introduction to Embedded Systems - A Cyber-Physical Systems Approach, First Edition
column2: This book is intended for students at the advanced undergraduate level or the introductory graduate level, and for practicing engineers and computer scientists who wish to understand the engineering principles of embedded systems.

column1: Structure and Interpretation of Signals and Systems, Second Edition
column2: This book introduces the mathematical models used to design and understand signals and systems, based on several years of successful classroom use at the University of California, Berkeley. Calculus is the only prerequisite.

column1: [No longer freely accessible] The Elements of Computing Systems: Building a Modern Computer from First Principles
column2: This textbook leads students through twelve chapters and projects that gradually build a basic hardware platform and a modern software hierarchy from the ground up.

column1: An Introduction to the Science of Statistics: From Theory to Implementation, Preliminary Edition
column2: An introductory textbook, dedicated to a higher level of understanding of the concepts and practical applications of statistics. A solid grasp of concepts and structures in calculus and algebra is required.

column1: Introduction to Embedded Systems: A Cyber-Physical Systems Approach, Second Edition
column2: This book takes a cyber-physical approach to introduce the engineering concepts underlying embedded systems. The focus is on modeling, design, and analysis of cyber-physical systems, which integrate computation, networking, and physical processes.

column1: Foundations of Computer Science: C Edition
column2: This text combines the theoretical foundations of computing with essential discrete mathematics. It follows the same organization as its predecessor, Foundations of Computer Science (also published by W.H. Freeman), with all examples and exercises in C.

column1: The Engineering of Reliable Embedded Systems (1st Edition)
column2: The first edition of "Engineering of Reliable Embedded Systems" (ERES1) documents an industry-proven approach to the development of software for reliable, real-time embedded systems, based on the use of time-triggered (TT) architectures.

column1: Introduction to Numerical Methods and Matlab Programming for Engineers
column2: These notes were developed for a course on applied numerical methods for Civil Engineering and Mechanical Engineering. The main goals these lectures are to introduce concepts of numerical methods and introduce Matlab in an Engineering framework.

column1: An Introduction to Proofs and the Mathematical Vernacular
column2: This textbook helps students make the transition from being a user of mathematics to someone who can critically read and evaluate mathematical statements and being able to write mathematical explanations in clear, logically precise language.

column1: Multiagent Systems: Algorithmic, Game-Theoretic, and Logical Foundations
column2: A comprehensive introduction to Multiagent Systems, this textbook is written from a computer science perspective, while bringing together ideas from operations research, game theory, economics, logic, and even philosophy and linguistics.

column1: Numerical Algorithms: Methods for Computer Vision, Machine Learning, and Graphics
column2: This textbook presents a new approach to numerical analysis for modern computer scientists and introduces numerical modeling and algorithmic design from a practical standpoint and provides insight into the theoretical tools needed to support these skills.

column2: This book will teach you how to do data science with R: You'll learn how to get your data into R, get it into the most useful structure, transform it, visualize it and model it.

column1: 500 Lines or Less: Experienced Programmers Solve Interesting Problems
column2: This book provides you with the chance to study how 26 experienced programmers think when they are building something new. The programs you will read about in this book were all written from scratch to solve difficult problems.

column1: The Performance of Open Source Applications: Speed, Precision, and a Bit of Serendipity
column2: Written by real developers who have had to make an existing system faster or who had to design something to be fast in the first place, this book will help you become a better developer by letting you look over these experts' shoulders.

column1: R Packages: Organize, Test, Document, and Share Your Code
column2: This practical book shows you how to bundle reusable R functions, sample data, and documentation together by applying author's package development philosophy.

column1: Advanced R: An Essential Reference for Intermediate and Advanced R Programmers
column2: This book presents useful tools and techniques for attacking many types of R programming problems, helping you avoid mistakes and dead ends.

A 13-part, integrated-media resource created for adult learners and high school teachers. The series covers the broad scope of human knowledge through the study of mathematics and its relevance in the world today.

column1: Intro Stat with Randomization and Simulation, 1st Edition
column2: This textbook takes a different approach, where the foundations for inference are provided using randomization and simulation methods. Once a solid foundation is formed, a transition is made to traditional approaches.
A book about trouble spots, oddities, traps, glitches in R. If you are using R and you think you’re in hell, this is a map for you.

column1: The Elements of Data Analytic Style
column2: A guide for people who want to analyze data. This book is focused on the details of data analysis that sometimes fall through the cracks in traditional statistics classes and textbooks.
This book teaches you to use R to effectively visualize and explore complex datasets.

column1: The Data Science Handbook: Advice and Insights from 25 Amazing Data Scientists
column2: A compilation of in-depth interviews with 25 data scientists from a wide selection of backgrounds, disciplines, and industries, where they share their insights, stories, and advice.
If you've toyed with Linux and never really caught on to what's happening or have used a graphical interface without really touching the command line this book is for you.

column1: D3 Tips and Tricks v3.x: Interactive Data Visualization in a Web Browser
column2: Over 600 pages of tips and tricks for using d3.js, one of the leading data visualization tools for the web. It's aimed at getting you started and moving you forward. Includes over 50 downloadable code examples.

A free intermediate algebra text distributed to all students at College of the Redwoods who are enrolled in Math 120 course.

A textbook about project management tailored specifically for instructional designers, intended for use in graduate programs in educational technology.

column2: Stochastic games provide a versatile model for reactive systems that are affected by random events. This dissertation advances the algorithmic theory of stochastic games to incorporate multiple players, whose objectives are not necessarily conflicting.

column1: Playful Identities: The Ludification of Digital Media Cultures
column2: In this book, eighteen scholars examine the increasing role of digital media technologies in identity construction through play. It features the most recent insights in play and game studies, media research, and identity studies.

column2: This book is about digital games, the people who play digital games, and how they play them. It demonstrates how useful and generalizable concepts can be developed from understanding digital games as they are played.
A set of exercises and problems for a (more or less) standard beginning calculus sequence.

column2: This book demystifies the architecture and protocols of computers as they communicate over the Internet. It was written for everyone - no technical knowledge is required.

column2: This book helps engineers build a bridge from what they know of IPv4 to the new concepts of IPv6. Includes a series of very detailed labs that can be done with generic PCs and open source software, to create a full featured IPv6 testbed network.

column2: Through a collection of essays and case studies, leading visionaries and practitioners both inside and outside of government share their ideas on how to achieve and direct this emerging world of online collaboration, transparency, and participation.

column1: Probabilistic Models in the Study of Language
column2: This textbook covers the topic of using probabilistic models in scientific work on language ranging from experimental data analysis to corpus work to cognitive modeling.

column1: [No longer publicly accessible] Learning Deep Architectures for AI
column2: This monograph discusses the motivations and principles regarding learning algorithms for deep architectures, in particular those exploiting as building blocks unsupervised learning of single-layer models.
A free, full-length, and interactive statistics textbook. It is a companion site of "VassarStats: Web Site for Statistical Computation".

This handbook provides a comprehensive guide to statistical concepts, methods and tools, with many examples being provided using a variety of software tools such as R, MATLab and SPSS to clarify the concepts discussed.

column1: The Nature of Code: Simulating Natural Systems with Processing
column2: This book focuses on a range of programming strategies and techniques behind computer simulations of natural systems, from elementary concepts in mathematics and physics to more advanced algorithms that enable sophisticated visual results.

column2: This book provides a comprehensive guide to concepts, methods and tools related to Geospatial Analysis, with many examples being provided using a variety of software tools such as ArcGIS, Idrisi, Grass, Surfer and many others to clarify the concept.

column1: Designing Business Information Systems: Apps, Websites, and More
column2: This book is designed to help students get a feel for what a career in MIS would be like. Most of this book is a case. Tools are introduced when needed, and only to the extent needed, to get at each part of the case.

column1: GIS Commons: An Introductory Textbook on Geographic Information Systems
column2: This textbook is an introduction to GIS, but most of the chapter's concepts are also applicable to other geotechnologies including remote sensing, global positioning systems (GPS), Internet mapping, and virtual globes.

column1: Project Management Skills for All Careers
column2: This textbook provides students with project management skills they can apply in any chosen profession.

column1: Information Systems for Business and Beyond
column2: In this book, you will be introduced to the concept of information systems, their use in business, and the larger impact they are having on our world.

column2: This book sets out the new field of software innovation. It organizes the existing scientific research into eight simple heuristics - guiding principles for organizing a system developer's work-life so that it focuses on innovation.

column1: The GAMEiT handbook: A framework of game based learning pedagogy
column2: This handbook illustrates how games or elements of games can be included in educational practice, and to what end.

column2: To understand how a computer works, it is essential to understand the digital circuits which make up the CPU. This text introduces the most important of these digital circuits; adders, decoders, multiplexers, D flip-flops, and simple state machines.

column1: Game Theory: An Open Access Textbook

column1: The Linux Sysadmins Guide to Virtual Disks - From the Basics to the Advanced
column2: This book demonstrates the core concepts of virtual disk management. Topics include helper utilities, disk formats, troubleshooting tips, performance considerations, and comprehensive appendices.

A textbook that covered 32-bit protected mode assembly programming.
An advanced reading on the concept, principle and structures of design patterns.

column1: [No longer publicly accessible] Core Servlets and JavaServer Pages
column2: Explains the role of servlets and JavaServer Pages (JSP) in creating e-commerce sites, dynamic web sites, and web-enabled services.
A definitive reference for GNU Bash, the standard GNU command-line interpreter.
Guides you through the many different regions of a GNU/Linux system with a focus on getting your desktop environment to do what you want it to do.

column1: A Practical Theory of Programming, Second Edition
column2: Describes theory of programming as something that will provide a much greater degree of precision by providing a method of calculation to software engineers.
Presents the results of a series of research projects related to object-oriented software composition that were carried out within the Object Systems Group at the University of Geneva.
Presents a rigorous treatment of most elementary program-development constructs, including iteration, recursion, procedures, parameters, modules and data refinement.

column1: The ePMbook - Project and Programme Management
column2: The ePMbook presents learning and wisdom based on practical experience, drawn from many programmes and projects. It does not try to define a methodology - there are far too many methodologies. It focuses on issues and how to deal with them.
The manual provides tutorial examples for new users of CVS, as well as the definitive reference documentation for every CVS command and configuration option.
A new version control system designed to supplant CVS.

column1: [No longer freely accessible] Python Standard Library
column2: Based in part on over 3,000 newsgroup articles written by Python veteran Fredrik Lundh since 1995, this book provides brief descriptions and sample scripts for all standard modules in the Python 2.0 library.

column1: Incompatibilities Between ISO C and ISO C++
column2: This long document lists the incompatibilities between C99 (C standard ratified by ISO in 1999) and C++98 (C++ standard ratified by ISO in 1998).

column1: Industrial Strength C++; Rules and Recommendations
column2: Programming standard for a particular company or project.

column1: Style Guides for C and C++
column2: Collection of documents with rules, guidelines, and recommendations for C and C++ coding practices.
Describes Unix development that Unix experts know, but aren't aware that they know. It delves on the 'why-to', not the 'how-to'.
Teaches GNU users how to write software in C.
An introduction to the C++ language, with no attempt to teach object-oriented design to any depth.

column1: The Psychology of Menu Selection: Designing Cognitive Control at the Human/Computer Interface
column2: Provides detailed theoretical and empirical information of interest to software designers and human/computer interaction specialists and researchers.

column1: The CVS Book: Open Source Development with CVS
column2: A complete introduction, tutorial, and reference to the Concurrent Versions System (CVS), along with a detailed survey of the sustoms and conventions of Open Source development, and how CVS fits into them.

column1: Technical Writing: Online Textbook / Power Tools for Technical Communication
column2: Introduces the readers to some of the most important aspects of writing in the world of science, technology, and business.

column1: Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
column2: Advanced introduction to computer science and programming.
Collection of 965 problems on the design, analysis, and verification of algorithms.

column1: Data Structures and Algorithms With Object-Oriented Design Patterns in Java
column2: Covers the fundamentals of data structures and algorithms -- the basic elements from which large and complex software artifacts are built -- using Java programming language.

column1: Data Structures and Algorithms with Object-Oriented Design Patterns in C++
column2: Promotes object-oriented design using C++ and illustrates the use of the emerging object-oriented design patterns.
Methods for solving problems on computers and the costs (usually the running time) of using those methods.
Describes how to use Linux and FreeBSD on the same system.
Covers the installation and day to day use of FreeBSD 4.6-RELEASE.

column1: Thinking in Python: Design Patterns and Problem-Solving Techniques
column2: Learns about object-oriented programming by seeing objects used in many different situations using Python.
Introduces Zope, an open-source web application server. Explains how to manage dynamic content and implement advanced topics such as relational databases and scripting, using Zope.

column1: [No longer freely available] The Python Imaging Library Handbook
column2: Describes the Python Imaging Library, which adds image processing capabilities to Python interpreter.
Covers the basic theory of computer programming and the basic techniques needed to solve problems using Python. For absolute beginners on web programming.

column1: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist : Learning with Python
column2: An introduction to programming using Python, one of the best languages for beginners.

column1: GUI Programming with Python: QT Edition
column2: Focuses on application development using PyQt, a library extension to the Python programming language.

column1: Dive Into Python - Python from novice to pro
column2: For experienced programmers. Period.
Describes Tkinter module (Tk interface), the standard Python interface to the Tk GUI toolkit.
Author Eric S. Raymond anatomizes his successful open source project, fetchmail, as a test of some surprising theories about software engineering suggested by the history of Linux.

column1: Open Sources: Voices from the Open Source Revolution
column2: Collection of essays from the leaders of the Free Software / Open Source movement, explaining why the majority of the Internet's servers use Open Source technologies for everything from the operating system to Web serving and email.

column1: Free as in Freedom, Richard Stallman's Crusade for Free Software
column2: A biographical snapshots of GNU project founder Richard Stallman with the political, social and economic history of the free software movement.
A catalog of 23 generally useful patterns for writing object-oriented software, each of them is presented with at least one complete, visual Java program.
Written for professionals involved in the development of medium, large, and distributed systems. Consists of instructions on how to put key object-oriented concepts to work in software construction.

column1: [No longer freely accessible] Java: An Object First Approach
column2: A thorough introduction to the production of software artefacts, a process known as software development, using Java programming language.

column1: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming Using C++
column2: Introduces object-orientation as a new programming concept which should help the reader in developing high quality software.

column1: Adaptive Object-Oriented Software: The Demeter Method with Propagation Patterns
column2: Presents a complete methodology for adaptive programming in any object-oriented language.
A compelling true story of the rise of the computer underground and the crimes of an elite group of hackers who took on the forces of the establishment.

column1: [No longer freely available] Trapped in the Net: The Unanticipated Consequences of Computerization
column2: A closer look at how the products of computerization technology have become embedded in all our lives, forcing us to narrow the scope of our choices, our modes of control, and our experiences with the real world.

column1: The Hacker Crackdown: Law and Disorder on the Electronic Frontier
column2: A classic work highlights the 1990 assault on hackers, on the arrest of suspected illicit hackers and other computer-based law-breakers.

column1: The Future Does Not Compute, Transcending the Machines in Our Midst
column2: Reveals many reasons why we should not just accept the promises of a technological paradise without reflecting on its consequences.

column1: Moths to the Flame : The Seductions of Computer Technology
column2: Addresses important issues concerning the role of computers on privacy, war, and poverty.
A complete reference for new Linux users who wish to set up and administer their own Linux home computer, workstation and/or their home or small office network.
Provide a single reference for beginner and experienced network administrators.

column1: The Linux Kernel: Blueprints for World Domination
column2: Describes the principles and mechanisms that Linux uses; how and why the Linux kernel works the way that it does.

Intended for undergraduate students who have some programming experience and may even have written a few programs in Prolog. Requires no knowledges in any formal course in either propositional or predicate logic.

column1: Logic, Programming and Prolog, Second Edition
column2: Introduces topics such as concurrency and equational and constraint logic programming. Balances between a clear and authoritative treatment of the theory and a practical, problem-solving approach to its applications.

column1: An Introduction to Logic Programming Through Prolog
column2: Introduces logic programming, combining three essential components: the declarative nature of logic itself, the programming techniques needed to write effective programs, and the efficient implementation of logic programming by computer.
Shows how to write Linux system's device drivers, for technical programmers who face the need to deal with the inner levels of a Linux box.
Shows how to write more sophisticated programs with features such as multi-processing, multi-threading, interprocess communication, and interaction with hardware devices for the GNU/Linux system.

column1: The Linux Cookbook - Tips and Techniques for Everyday Use
column2: Consists over 1,500 time-saving recipes and hints for busy Linux users, sorted in sections by the tasks they perform or the objects they work on.

column1: Linux: Rute User's Tutorial and Exposition
column2: Covers GNU/Linux system administration, for popular distributions like RedHat and Debian, as a tutorial for new users and a reference for advanced administrators.
Follows on the Linux From Scratch book, introduces and guides the reader through additions to the system including networking, X support, sound support, printer support and scanner support.
Teaches you how a Linux system works internally and provides the steps necessary to build your own custom Linux system.
Focuses on the needs of the new Linux user and on desktop Linux applications.

column1: Debian GNU/Linux: Guide to Installation and Usage
column2: Aimed at readers who are new to Debian GNU/Linux, assuming no prior knowledge of GNU/Linux or other Unix-like systems.

Written to help every Linux user, from the newbie who's just getting started, to someone who's been around the block once or twice and wants to have a handy broad reference to all the capabilities of Caldera's OpenLinux.
Teaches the basics of how browsers communicate with servers and how to write your own customized Web clients to automate common tasks.

column1: The Perl Reference Guide / Perl 5 Pocket Reference
column2: A typeset quick reference guide to Perl version 5.004. Contains a concise description of all Perl 5 statements, functions, variables and lots of other useful information.
A compilation of course notes for the students at Cardiff University, spans from introductory to advanced application.
A tutorial book for the Perl language, preferred for anyone with a knowledge equivalent to a first-year of college computer science courses.
Teaches you how to use the Perl programming language, designed to serve a broad range of readers from novice to advanced.

column1: CGI Programming on the World Wide Web
column2: Focuses on the workings of the CGI specification down to the tiniest detail.
An undergraduate text in the theory of programming languages.

column1: How To Design Programs: An Introduction To Programming and Computing
column2: Exposes readers to two fundamentally new ideas: program design guidelines and programming environment.

column1: So you want to be a Computer Game Developer?
column2: Reveals what it takes to develop a game and make a living of it. A recommended guide for game developers.

column1: Simulating Humans: Computer Graphics Animation and Control
column2: The methodology details and software environment of incorporating real-time interactive manipulation and display for human figures.
A complete guide to developing 2D Linux games. Discusses important multimedia toolkits and teaches the basics of Linux game programming.

column1: Michael Abrash's Graphics Programming Black Book
column2: From the person who optimized Quake himself, features assembler optimization on graphics programming using Intel CPUs, from the 8088 on to the early Pentium lines.
A report of a graduate project, to examine whether the use of Java for games is advantageous compared to the current languages of choice, C and C++.

column1: Design and Architecture of a Portable and Extensible Multiplayer 3D Game Engine
column2: Describes the inner working of Parsec, a non-commercial space-shooter game available for download free of charge.

column1: [No longer publicly accessible] Computer Animation: Algorithms and Techniques
column2: A draft of computer animation class notes intended for computer graphics programmers who want to learn the basics of computer animation programming.

column1: Action Arcade Adventure Set: The Best Way to Create Action Arcade Games in C
column2: Shows how to create side-scroller games in a way that anyone who has programmed in C can undertand.

column1: Writing Bug-Free C Code for Windows
column2: Describes an alternate class methodology that provides complete data hiding and fault-tolerant run-time type checking of objects in C programs.
Provides C++ programmers with a practical, real-world approach to program optimization.

column1: Numerical Recipes in C: The Art of Scientific Computing
column2: Combines general discussion, analytical mathematics, algorithmics, and actual working programs. That is, a cookbook on numerical computation.

column1: C++?? : A Critique of C++, 3rd Edition
column2: Analysis of some of the flaws of C++.

column1: [No longer freely accessible] C++: A Dialog (formerly: Who's Afraid of C++?)
column2: Teaches C++ to complete novices, people without a computing background.
An excellent tutorial to mastering C++, emphasizing on practical programming.
A starting point for programming using the C++ language.

column1: How To Think Like A Computer Scientist: C++ Version
column2: Guidelines to problem-solving as the most important skill for a computer scientist.

column1: C++ In Action: Industrial Strength Programming Techniques
column2: Tutorials on object-oriented programming, language features specific to C++, and the large-scale aspects of software development.
For knowledgeable users of C who would like to make the transition to C++.
Guidelines to build a good programming style into your code.
A reference for introductory Computer Science courses that use C++ as an implementation language.

column1: Think Java: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist (Version 5)
column2: An introduction to Java programming for beginners. It is tailored for students preparing for the Computer Science Advanced Placement (AP) Exam, but it is for anyone who wants to learn Java.

column1: Semantics with Applications: A Formal Introduction
column2: The book covers the foundations of structural operational semantics (where computations consist of many small steps) and natural semantics (where computations consist of one big step).
Presents Gentle, an integrated system for compiler writers that supports the description of compilers at a very high level and relieves users from the need to deal with implementation details.

column1: Partial Evaluation and Automatic Program Generation
column2: This book is about partial evaluation, a program optimization technique also known as program specialization. It presents general principles for constructing partial evaluators for a variety of programming languages, with examples of applications.
A fifteen-part tutorial series, written from 1988 to 1995, on the theory and practice of developing language parsers and compilers from scratch.
A practical approach to understanding implementations of non-strict functional languages using lazy graph reduction.
The online manual for Flex, a fast lexical analyser generator, generating programs that perform pattern-matching on text.

column1: Compiler Construction using Flex and Bison
column2: A guide to compiler construction using compiler's compiler tools like Flex and Bison. Using both tools, you can focus on the concept of compiler without the hassle of building a compiler from scratch.
The online manual of Bison, a general-purpose parser generator that converts a grammar description for an LALR context-free grammar into a C program to parse that grammar.

column1: A Compact Guide to Lex & Yacc
column2: Explains how to construct a compiler using lex and yacc, the tools used to generate lexical analyzers and parsers.
A clear, accessible, and thorough discussion of many different parsing techniques with their interrelations and applicabilities, including error recovery techniques.

column1: Compilers and Compiler Generators: an introduction with C++
column2: Combines theory, practical applications and the use of compiler writing tools to give students a solid introduction to the subject of programming language translation.
Explains the concepts of Java Servlets and provides a step-by-step tutorial for writing HTTP Servlets with complete source code for the example Servlets.

column1: Securing Java: Getting Down to Business with Mobile Code
column2: Helps the reader to separate fact from fiction when it comes to mobile code security from throughout the entire Java range.
Covers everything needed to start in EJB development, from the basics of EJB architecture to developing transactional, scalable, and secure multiuser enterprise applications.

column1: Jan Newmarch's Guide to JINI Technologies
column2: The most popular on-line tutorial for Jini, Sun's Java based technology that makes transparent distributed computing possible.

column1: Inside The Java Virtual Machine, 2nd Edition
column2: Describes the Java virtual machine, the abstract computer on which all Java programs run, and several core Java APIs that have an intimate relationship to the virtual machine.

column1: EJB Design Patterns: Advanced Patterns, Processes, and Idioms
column2: Reveals high-level design patterns and critical EJB-specific implementation issues, illustrated with source code. Also contains a catalog of twenty advanced EJB patterns.
An introduction to using the Java programming language in concurrent or multithreaded applications.

column1: Advanced Programming for the Java 2 Platform
column2: Helps you navigate the Java APIs and fast-track your project development time. Includes the design, development, test, and deployment phases for an enterprise-worthy auction application.
A massive tutorial covers many of the nooks and crannies of the language, with each section has sample exercises that let you try out and expand your Java knowledge.

column1: Objects and Java: Building Object-Oriented, Multi-Threaded Applications with Java
column2: A work-in-progress book that focuses on how to do object-oriented, multi-threaded design and programming with the Java language.

column1: Introduction To Programming With Java, Version 8.1.2
column2: A free introductory computer programming textbook that uses Java as the language of instruction. It is suitable for use in an introductory programming course and for people who are trying to learn programming on their own.

column1: Introduction to Computer Science using Java
column2: Compilation of lecture notes which cover most of a beginning course in computer science using Java in CSCU Computer Science Department.

column1: Essentials of the Java Programming Language: A Hands-On Guide
column2: Walks through how to use the Java 2 platform software to develop a general electronic-commerce network application that uses common Java 2 platform features.
Covers the Java language from the ground up as well as the AWT including threads, layout managers, exceptions, event handling, data structures, input and output, and a lot more.

column1: Bleeding at the Keyboard: A Guide to Modern Programming with Java
column2: A step by step guide on learning Java.
A guide to all the fundamental parts of GNOME. Teaches you how to write a complete GNOME application, from front to back.

Guidelines to fully understand Samba and its potential. Recommended for typical system administrators who want to reduce the complexity and the workload of their work environment, and keeping it running smoothly.

column1: Practical Programming in Tcl and Tk, 3rd Edition
column2: A practical guide to help the beginner as well as the expert to get the most out of Tcl and Tk.
Teaches the reader how to take advantage of all that the KDE libraries have to offer, assuming some knowledge of C++ at the beginner level or better.
Describes how to write a Gnome application using the Gnome libraries and tools.
Covers image manipulation concepts and which GIMP tools are the most effective for the implementation.
A tutorial for autoconf, automake and libtool, that describes how these tools work together.
Teaches you about the awk language and how you can use it effectively. Also describes gawk, the GNU implementation of awk.
The official and complete guide to Gimp that will help you learn how to create great art in Gimp step by step.
The user's guide for Cygwin, the popular GNU development tools and utilities for Windows NT and 9x.
